This Company's system of submarine telegraph

South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE WAR OF THE FUTURE.
div.p: Yesterday’s telegrams container! a significant announcement of the opinion of the American Press as to the inevitableness of the war be¬tween Japan and the United States. The trouble has only just commenced, hut as the 1 Spectator" remarks in an article on the subject it may rapidly become serious. The yellow peoples are very proud and very sensitive.

They do not acknowledge—as, for example the negroes have hitherto done—that there are any inherent inequality between themselves and the white men ; and, not acknowledging it, the weight of argument is entirely upon their side. They do not even understand why their "intrusion" is disliked, and they see their way to reprisals which might in certain contingencies—-as, for instance, a great Euro¬pean war—develop into active hostilities. The subject should therefore be dealt with before the Governments have caught fire, and while the classes which are not affected in- both sets of countries are prepared to listen to reasonable argument.

That argument should, we think, be based upon the assumption, that the races will, for the present at all events, do well to keep apart. Their instinctive hostility—or shall we say jealousy?- may, and probably will gradually die away; but it has lasted for ages, and has become in the course of those ages one of the fixed conditions of thought end feeling among the masses, making a just equality of treatment for the moment nearly impossible. The Far Eastern States, for example, cannot confine their »migration to families only, and families of the I test character, while the white States cannot coerce their uneducated populations into accept¬ing their yellow competitors as friends and helpers. The movement, if it became general, must inevitably develop small industrial civil wars; and diplomatists may on that ground alone use all their energies to prevent by agree-ment what must otherwise prove a disturbing contact, in the absence of which peace between the races might reign for ages.

But, the diplomatists will ask with reason, on what lines are we to suggest agreements I They will be difficult to arrange, hut they are not altogether impossible As we understand the matter, none of the Far Eastern Govern-ments are particularly anxious that their subjects should emigrate. On the Other hand, Europeans and Americans of the working class do not seek the Far Eastern States as places for settlement. It must therefore be possible for the Governments on both sides to discourage emigration; and, for instance, the Government of India now does whenever the demand comes from pièces which it considers unsuitable under the prevailing conditions, or unwhole- some by reason of climate. That Government has once or twice used its reserved power to control emigration in a very decided way, once nearly milling the colony of Réunion, for exam¬ple, which depended upon« supply of Indian labour, when it suspected or knew that the emigrants, under a delusion about the danger from cholora, were being-harshly treated These government once made, the question would be under the official control of the responsible Governments, who might, by intro¬ducing a passport system, prevent over-nume¬rous immigration without preventing, or even restricting, the ordinary movements of com¬merce or shipping. They could pass all traders' agents or bagmen, while forbidding coolies to lie taken on hoard. Diplomatists may easily make better suggestions than this, but this is the object they should seek, and seek now, before overwhelming demand or habit of .'migration renders "precautions hopeless, or so burdensome to great “interests" that the Foreign Offices would try to longer retain a free hand. They may rely on it that it will be many years, perhaps many decades, before the jea¬lousy of the white workmen will subside; while it is most, unreasonable to expect that the For Eastern populations, which are so steadily claiming their place in the arrangements of the world, will for ever bear to see their children insulted and injured because of an abstract theory that their presence is injurious to alien civilizations, For the moment the Foreign (Justices may imagine that the East can make no effective reprisals, and therefore they may neglect the subject ; but that is an illusion resembling that of the Russian statesmen who fancied, before the war, that Japan was a little Bower which, even if it felt affronted, could he safely defied or coerced. These States are not minor Bowers, but are as sensitive as if they were; and if affronted, they may find means of asserting themselves which will produce a sense, if not of dismay, at least of perplexity in very great Governments indeed.

div.head: Cattle Plague
div.p: During the week ending January 28 six cases of bovine typhus were reported for the whole of Egypt. Three took plaoe in the Fashn district and three near Beni Maiar.

div.head: Egyptian Shipbuilding
div.p: During last year six steamships, of 2,666 tons gross, and two sailing vessels, of 1,200 tons gross, were launched in the United Kingdom for Egypt. In 1905 only one vessel was launched, and in 1904 six.

div.head: Hotel Semiramis.
div.p: As already announced, the inauguration of the Semiramis Hotel, Cairo, will take place on Thursday, 7th inst. There will be a reception daring the afternoon, and a dinner and a grand ball in the evening. Numerous invitations have been sent out.

div.head: Savoy Fancy Dress Ball.
div.p: The management of the Savoy Hotel have decided to issue invitations for a fancy-dress ball on Tuesday, 19th inst. These annual balls are always among the events of the season, and this one will doubtless be as successful as any of those of past years.

div.head: Captain Spelterini.
div.p: Those in search of a novel entertainment should Dot miss the opportunity offered by a lantern lecture with slides from instantaneous photographs taken from the balloon by Captain Spelterini, the famous aeronaut, which is to be given at the 8avoy Hotel, Cairo, tomorrow, at 9.80 p.m. The views to be shown are those taken above the Alps and id Egypt, and the lecture is to be delivered in English by Mr. J. W. Congdon. We can heartily recommend the lecture as one of extreme and unusual interest.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: THe Suez Canal reciepts for January were Fr. 9,207,939.21 as against Fr. 9,578,609.79 for January 1906. The passenger returns for the month were 21,035 viz., 7,000 civilians, 7,972 military, and the 6,065 pilgrims. The nationality of the military passengers was as follows: - 4,950 British, 1,007 Germans, 850 French, 730 Turkish, 237 Dutch, 166 Portugese, and 32 Italian. The total shipping for the month was 340,153 northward and 187 southward boud; 207 being British, 45 German, and 22 French.

div.head: New Khedivial Hotel.
div.p: We are glad to note that the new management of the New Khedivial Hotel, Cairn, is making itself felt, and that the hotel is gaining in public favour. Mr. J. Vooles, the present manager, is running the house is strict accordance with the principles of a family hotel and meeting with deserved success. Among the visitors staying there was of note the names of Admiral and Mrs. Dickins Mrs. Wyly, Mrs. Woostor, Mrs. Subring, Mrs Merril, Mr. Beresford, Mr. Tod, Mrs. Moffat, Mrs. FillioD, Miss Blanc, Dr. and Mrs. Asfar Mr., Mrs., and Miss Trad, Mr. and Mrs Ziensen, Mr. and Mrs. Lineskal, Mr. and Mrs Bpagnolo, Mr. aud Mrs. d'Broille, Mrs. E Bilberman, Mr. and Mrs Nicole, Mr. and Mrs. Miller

div.head: Recital At Shepherds
div.p: Miss Julie written is rapidly establishing he fame in Cairo for her marvelous cleverness a palmist, and .on Friday she hopes to add to her repertoire by appearing before the public as a “racontense." Under the name of Hope Hathaway she has already charmed her audiences in London with her clever sketches and humorous recitals ; and her appearance in this capacity will be doubly welcome in Cairo, where such entertainments are almost unknown. The first of her ' One-hour recitals will take place at Shepheard’s Hotel at 9 o’clock on Friday evening ; the tickets being fixed is the moderate prices of 20 and 10 piastros Mil Critten hopes to give a series of these recitals at the other hotels in Cairo, and doubtless she will meet with a hearty reception.

div.head: Motorcar Plunges Into the Sea
div.p: A singular mishap occurred yesterday evening, about six o'clock, in Alexandria habour the scene of the accident being quay No. 1 The motor 'bos of the New Victoria Hotel was standing there waiting for passengers from JJ Moss 8.3. Menepthat, when, owing to a roar (engines were reversed, and before the oar could be stopped it plunged into to no’s, four fathoms deep. A tremendous ensued as soon as the car touched the sea the cold water presumably affecting the vap riser and the cylinders, causing them to bur with a loud reverberation, much to the alar of a large crowd of bystanders. The ohanffe managed to jump off in time. It is possible that the oar may be recovered this afternoon Divers report that structural damage is but slight.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA’S PORT-
div.p: HARBOUR IMPROVEMENTS.-
PROGRESS OF A GREAT WORK.

Considerable progress has been made of late in the great works intended to improve the accommodation of the port of Alexandria. The four most important undertakings are : (1) the insurance of the outer harbor at the cost of L.E. 120,000 by prolonging the great break water and by throwing out a breakwater From the new cattle port quay; f2) thpcoo- dtrnotion of three new timber quays for six ships ; (3) the construction of a new coal quay for eight ships;, (4) the construction of the Arsenal quay with berths for four ships ; (5) the creation of a new pass capa¬ble of allowing tho largest commercial steamer to pass safley in and out of the port in all weathers, and, in conjunction with the existing pass, to provide an alternative exit and egress, in ease of a block in one of them. We will deal with the present state of each of these works in the order given above.
THE BREAKWATER

The two branches of the breakwater will be each 450 metres in length. The extension from the land side, which juts out from the quarantine pail port, has only just begun to be made, and will not be finished before May 1st, 1908. The work on the prolongation of the great breakwater began last August, and already one hundred metres op to the level of the sea have been built. Three hundred metres have been constructed to a distance of three mrtres below sea level. The whole extent of this branch will be complete next November.
TIMBER QUAYS

The new quays for the timber ships are situated between the Kamarieh harbonr and the graving dock The embankments are complete op to the beginning of the molos, and a hundred metros of the first mole are finished.

A million cubic metres of earthworks have been executed, and a thousand block of concrete, twelve cubic metres each. are ready to be placed in position. All the three quays will be finished and ready to receive ships by the 1st March, 1908.
COAL QUAYS

Two berths of the new coal quays were finished last March. A third berth was com¬pleted in December last, and a fourth last month The fifth berth will be ready by-next August. The three other berth«, of the total of eight, will be ready by the 1st January, 1909. The construction of the new timber and coal quays is most necessary to prevent the in further congestion of the port. In 1895, 615.000 tons of coal wore imported. In 1905 this figure rose to 1,132 635 tons, and last year to 1,109,754 tons. Thu value of the wood imported in 1895 was L.E . 496,030. It, 190.5 the wood imports amounted to L.B. 1,329,219 in value.
ARSENAL QUAY

Two berths, together with the sheds, will be handed over by the engineer on the 1st January next. Two others will be completed by the first June 1908. The site of the old jetty attached to this quay, which was made in 1810. has already been partly dredged, and 200.000 square 'Cubic metres of embankment have been constructed there. The old walls will be utilized for the works.
THE NEW PASS

Vessels will be able to use the now pass from next July. The advantage of the new pass, in view of the continual increase in the size of commercial steamers, is obvious. Although, in perfectly smooth water, tho largest commercial steamer. When in light draught not exceeding 28 feet, might enter the port with safety, they could not do so if laden with cargo, or during bad weather ,and, in any case, might, after enter¬ing, be indefinitely detained in the port until they could leave with safety. All these difficult tasks will he things of the past by next July. The work has necessitated considerable labour. Two hopper barges, a dredged, and a tug I arrived last year for the enterprise. dredged total cost was about L.E. 50,060 and they wore supplied by Symouds of Reufrew. The British Admiralty lent the Egyptian Government two powerful rook dredgers They have been at work for some time, and have nearly finished the new pass. The Admiralty dredgers have contributed greatly to the economy of the undertaking, and have proved them elves admirably adapted for the work, making it impossible to dispense with the delay and expense of blasting operations.

div.head: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE.
div.p: A MUCH-DISCUSSED APPOINTMENT.

The question of the appointment of a new resident of the Native Court of Appeal be dubbed a considerable amount of discussion in le native and European Press, and complaint live been read that the probable passing over to Afifi Bey in favor of Yehia Bey Ibrahim is mtrary to the regulations of the Ministry. ; is also stated that Yehia Bay is junior not aly to Fig Bey, but to Magda Bay. ‘and .tuned Bey Zulfioar.

But as a matter of fact Magda Bey and Yehia ay Ibrahim entered the Court of Appeal on 10 game day (June 27, 1892), while Zifikat Bey was only appointed on February 29, 1896. in any case the appeal of a Cairo contemporary ) the Deoreo of November, 1893, appears to s beside the mark. Art. 11 of this Deoree that "L'avanoement d'une olasse k nne at re, d’une mime fonotion k one autre, auront eu en tenant oompto du mfritt et di rancitn itf des oandidats." This article is of general application placed in Section I of the Decree des Magistrate" and does not refer to an; judicial appointment In any case it is explicitly »ted that "merit" most be reckoned with juiority in the choice of a magistrate, and in raotioe penior judges have been passed ovei or the posts of vice-president or president of a 'oort on the ground that they did not posses so requisite authority and the necessary administrative ospioity. In this case we understand that the Minister of Justice and the dioial Advisor have been advised by competent authorities as to the merits of the conditions for the presidency of the Native Court of Appeal. Under the circumstances we do not assume what grounds the cry of "injustice" has been raised by one of our contemporaries wit! Reference to the appointment in question.

div.head: EXPEDITION IN THE FAYOUM.
div.p: Professor Osborn, of the American Museum of Natural History, has left Mena House Hotel for the northern Fayopm desert, accompanied by Mr. H. F. Farrar, of the Government Qaologioal Survey, and Messrs. Granger and Olsen, of his own staff. The object of the party is to further explore for the extinct mammalia discovered by the Geological Bur vey in 1902, and recently described by Mr. C. U. Andrews, of the British Museum. The most widely known of the fossils ate the small an ancestors of the elephants and the large horned quadrupeds named Arsinrctheria fter the ancient Egyptian Queen Arsinde. The British authorities, and especially Captain H. G. Lyons, director of the Geological Survey, have greatly facilitated the expedition. The mem¬bers of Professor Osborn’s staff have had pro¬longed training in their explorations in the deserts of the Rocky Mountain region, and it is hoped that the knowledge of the life of Egypt in Eocene and times may be still more widely extended.

div.head: THE UNION BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: A new bank is shortly to be established in Egypt entitled the Union Bank of Egypt. Fine premises are to be built for the Cairo head- office.

div.head: PLAGUE AT JEDDAH.
div.p: A telegram from Jeddah states that two fresh cases of plague have occurred there.

div.head: A REMARKABLE ESCAPE.
div.p: On Sunday afternoon, the children of Mr. Alexander Alderson, of Ramleh, while driving with their governess and nurse, were precipitated into the canal-drain ty the side of the road leading from the Mahraoudieh Canal to Sidi Gaber. It is supposed that the wheel of the sakieh frightened one of the horses, which fell, dragging the other horse and the carriage down the steep side of the drain (a drop of about four metres). The occupants of the carriage all rolled into the dirty, muddy water. Fortunately, the nurse retained her hold of the baby, and those were the wily ones not com-pletely immersed. 0 1 being polled oat by tho coachman (who behaved splendidly throughout) has oh'ldrou failed, for the moment, to re-ogoise each other, so hjsmeared were they with mud. It is a matter fur congratulation that so little harm was done by what might have been a very serious acidenta, for, had the arriage pinned its occupants beneath it, it is difficult to see how all could have been saved. As it was, beyond a slight bruise sustained by the ooaohman and a good deal of damage to tho carriage, no ono was any the worse for the upset. The horse, escaped injury except for a few cats. At the' moment of the accident Dr. Beytzand Mr. Nowan Antone were driving past and kindly took the dripping, mud-stained party home in their carriages.

We hear that the Municipality has had the orientation of covering this drain for some time. This is now the second accident that has occur¬red at this spot, and it is some satisfaction Io know that the work is to be began at once.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: Tho Ellerman liner Fabian sailed from Malta last evening, and is doe here on Friday morning with a general cargo.
The Ellerman liner Egyptian arrived at Liverpool last Sunday.
The Moss liner Menepthah arrived yesterday afternoon from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head: A. S. C.
div.p: QUESTION OF NEW SITE.

Sooner or later the present site of the Alexandria Sporting Club will have to be changed, for owing to the great rise in the value of building land in the immediate neighborhood of the city the site will become too valuable to remain in its present condition. The discussion of the pros and coos of this question has again come forward and a great deal of support is being given in favor of Soof. There is a considerable extent of un¬occupied laud there, and as it is near San Stefano and the Palace of the Khedivial Mother, it cannot be considered too far from Ramleh for the purpose.

Prince Omar Pasha Toolson, who is the president of the Alexandria Sporting Club, is in favor of the Sioux scheme, and it is anp ported by many local sportsmen, who consider that the project of transferring the A. 8. C. to Naught is to be deprecated claiming the space there is too cramped for a good race¬course. Moreover, Nouxha is too out-of- the- way for both the inhabitants of Ramleh as well as the Alexandrians and aff ords none of the advantages of Soof for the reaction of a splendid hippodrome. The latter is only a quarter of an hour from Alexandria by motor¬car and is convenient of access from tho R imleh line. The wide stretch of open country there is fat more suitable tor a racecourse than the umbrageous park-like gardens of Nouxha. Those beautiful gardens and delightful walks would have to be hopelessly maned to make win for a race course and all the other ape- appurtenances of a Sporting Club.

Another alternative scheme is the Badura Lakeside. The lake would have to be drain¬ed, which would not be a very difficult task, and the site is convenient. But it may well be argued that in years to come, owing to the enormous expansion of A exedra towards the east, this site will be in time found to fall a prey to the builder just as is the existing site. No snob objection can be urged against the Ohio of Sioux. In such a case as the selection of a new site for the Alexandria Sporting Club it is most necessary to look as far forward as possible, and from this point of view the Sioux site is unexceptionable.

Orb exhalent confrere the "Pare d’ Alex- Andrei" recently published an interesting article on this question, and strong'; supported the schema of Prince Omar Pa h t Toussaint. His Highness’s idea is also, in our opinion, a very happy one, and deserves local support. Sooner or later the new site of the Alexandria Sporting Club will have to be chosen, and tho sooner a definite decision is arrived at the better for the lab and its members. Prince Omar is to be congratulated on raising the question, and we hope that his idea will receive the support that it merits.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Port Said, Monday.

The R. M. S. Isis arrived hare this afternoon from England after having undergone repairs and will take her usual ran with the Brindisi mail next week. The 8.8. Peninsular, which has been carrying the mails doing the absence of the Isis, will, after transferring the mail on Wednesday, continue her journey to Bombay, where she will resume her usual run.
There was a ‘Bachelors’ Ball" at the Eastern Exchange last Friday. This boing the first English dance this season, there was a good attendance, and a very enjoyable evening was passed.

On Saturday the Port Said Club gave one of their delightful balls in the club rooms. About 150 guests were present, among whom we noticed H.E. the Governor, Judge Bond, the Italian and Greek Consuls, and Mr. Demount Dancing was kept up till after 4.80 a.m.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but in the spirit of fair play to a11, to pencil-within certain necessary limits- free.
VICTORIA COLLEGE.

To THE EDITOR OF THE ' Egyptian GAZETTE " Sir,—With reference to 'Casual Observer's" letter dated January 29 on this subject, I beg to say that I have no desire to add an ought to any of the figures contained in my letter of the 28th. Since writing my last letter I have enquired of Mr. Preston as to the actual weights of the girders and joists used in the construction of the College and out- buildings and am informed that the exact quantity is 454 tons, and not 10,000, IS estimated by "Casual Observer,” so that my estimate was not far off tho correct amount.

I am pleased to think that I am sufficiently advanced in my profession to be able to distinguish between hundreds and thousands of tons, which Bourns to be beyond the power of a mere ''Casual Observer."—Yore truly, "ENGINEER."
Alexandria, Feb. 1.
To MR. "CASUAL OBSERVER."

Sir,—When you pay your visit to the office of the hen. see. of the Victoria College accord¬ing to invitation, would you mind ei quiring if there is anything British about this building, except the Please let me know the results of your investigations in the usual way, and oblige,—Yours faithfully,
"INTERESTED.”
Alexandria, Feb. 1.
EAST AND WEST.
To THE EDITOR OF THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
Sir,— At the banquet that was held in honor of Mr. Robert on,. M.P., Mr. Dicey is reported to have said the following, which I translate from “Al Minibar" : —

‘The longer I stay in your bountiful country which I consider a second home to me ( I 1 I) I become convinced that between East and West there is a great abyss that cannot be roosted from either side."
In other words, he reiterates the two notorious lines of Kipling’s :
East is East, and West is West,
The twain she’ll I ever meet.

In answer I beg to refer Mr. Dioecy to the following excerpt from "A People In School,” by More Fielding Hall, if I remember correctly. She says : “There is no such thing as the Oriental mind, it. is only an expense for all dullness.”? In other words, E.st and West are a twain that may and will meet, and they have already met in favor of the former—the war o' Russia and Japan are not far away from us.
— Yours truly,
N. E. SHAHIN.
Cairo, 3rd February.

div.head: THE BRITISH CLUB.
div.p: The second annual general meeting of mem¬bers of the British Club, Alexandria, was held on Saturday night’, and was well attended. The accounts for 1906 were passed, and the hon. treasurer’s statement of the financial position of the lung was considered satisfactory. The rules, with slight modifications, were confirmed, and the following were elected to term together with 'he Finance Committee, which remains in force for two more years, the General Committee for 1907: Messrs. A. R Brown, T F Donovan, J G Hewett, J Liligers L'gage, Lou b, A. H M Harris. Randolph, Rolf Waddington, and the Rev. A. H. Longley. M . W F Sa-jeaiit was elected chairman, and Mr. P. W. Carver re¬elected hon. treasurer. The appointment of hon secretary was left to the General Comitten, who met later on and elected Mr. W. J Webb.

div.head: BRITISH RECREATION CLUB
div.p: A highly successful smoking concert was held in the British Recreation Club, Cairo, on Saturday 2nd inst. A large and varied programme was submitted and carried through with every sign of appreciation on the part of a full attendance. Panototre selections by Private James and Mr. C, Summers, cello solos by Band Sargeant Geogehegan, and violin solos by Bandsman Hobbs, were rendered with taste and feeling- and especially so this applies to the celo solos of Sergeant Geoghegan, who showed the touch of a master in all his efforts- and the repeated calls for encores to these artists proved their acceptance to the audience. Private Parrington, in his songs, "The Toilers: and :big Ben," Mr. Allen, in "walking out with Angelina: and "My Havannah Queen," Mr. S Ades in "I love you in velvet" and "The man behind", and Mr Carins in "what did I do?" and "Stop yer tickling' Jock," were enjoyable items, which were received with approbation and recalled in every instance. Trooper Fairclough showed his versatility in a skirt dance, the execution of which and his dress and general "get-up" revealed a close study of the music hall skirt dancer. Sapper Goodwin, in his songs, I'll be up your way next week" and "Ding Dong" literally "brought down the house" the former especially being received with uproarious mirth; his song following these, "The song that will live forever," proved him and equally capable artist even in a more serious vein. Piper McConnaschie and Day aroused the enthusiasm of the audience to a high pitch by a stately and dignified rendering of the sword to Piper McConnaschie's dancing, and to repeated calls they gave a combined selection of the bagpipes including a march ("Barren Rocks O'Aden") strathspey ("Miss Drummond of Perth") and reel ("My wooers be merry"). AN enjoyable evening culminated with "God save the King." A word of praise is due to Mr. C. Summers, the moving spirit of the entertainments committee, who worked indefatigably in organizing the smoker, and not only found time to well marshal his musical forces, but to contribute personally to the programme.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Duke of Norfolk, who is arriving in . Egypt immediately with the Duchess of Nor¬folk, has never been greatly given to foreign travel. Rome, of course, sees him on occasions, but the Bari Marshal of England is often to be found in the home country. Overseas, to be sure, he has of late years been once ; but that was when the Postmaster General resigned his office, and the captain of Sussex Yeomanry went to do yeoman’s service in South Africa with his people.

Lord Alan Ian Percy, second heir to the Dukedom of Northumberland after his brother Bari Percy, who is unmarried, has joined the Egyptian Army with the rank of Bombastic and has been posted to the Khartoum di-introit. He was a Lieutenant in the Grenadier Guards and served in South Africa in 1901.

Lady Caroline Gordon Lennox has returned to Loudon from Goodwood House, Chi Chester, and haves London in a few days for Egypt. Lady Caroline is a sister of the Duke of Rahmel and aunt of Lady Muriel Beckwith, who has been at Cairo for some time, her husband boing stationed with the Coldstream C cards.
The Earl and Countess of Lovelace aye coming to ‘Egypt about the middle of the month.

Captain Forbes and Lady Helen Forbes are passengers by the Orient-Pacific liner Ophir for Egypt. Earl Egerton of Tafton and the Dottithoes of Buckingham and C band is and Lady Clarke are also passengering by the same vessel

The passengers who left London lab week for Gibraltar, Marseilles, Port SAID, Aden, and Bombay in London : Prince of Coop- Behar, Major-General Been Powdl, Hon. R, F. Wilbraham-Bootleg, Sit E. C. and Lady Cox, Sir Philip Grey Egerton, Lady E. Hewett, Lady Antonia Maude, the Earl and Countess of Merth, the Hood. Mrs. C. Monk, Lady North, Comte de la Pasture, and Sir E. W. Robinson.
Sir William Gerstein will visit Asouzo on inspection during the work.
Ahmed Razip Bey, the well-known Young Turk leader, has arrived at Cairo, and will stay for several weeks in the Capital.

div.head: ENTERTAINMENT
div.p: There will be a CONCERT and DRAMATIC ENTERTAINMENT by Distinguished Amateurs at the Theatre, Mullah Pasha Barracks, in aid of the nursing branch of the Sailors and Soldiers’ Families’ Association, on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday evenings, the 21st, 22nd. and 28rd of February, at nine o'clock.
PRICES OF ADMISSION.

On Thursday and Saturday nights 6 P.T. and 2 P.T. (payable at the door). On Friday (Staff night) admission by ticket only. Reserv¬ed Beats numbered. Single Tickets 20 P.T. Family Tickets (to admit three) for P.T. Tickets for Friday, 22nd February, can be obtained from the following ladies: Mrs. Chapman, Ramleh; Mrs. Borton, Mohaheov Bey ; Mrs. Maspheraon Grant, Menatapha, and also from the Officers’ Mess, Mastapba.
